entry.title: Rethinking SAP SuccessFactors Org Design in the Age of Skills-Based Organizations
entry.content:
From Hierarchies to Capabilities: Rethinking SAP SuccessFactors Org Design in the Age of Skills-Based Organizations

Not long ago, an organization‚Äôs design could be read right off the walls of its office building: departments physically clustered together, managers‚Äô names on doors, and reporting lines as rigid as the floor plan itself. HR organizational structures, reflected in systems such as SAP HCM, mirrored this reality by modeling companies as networks of organizational units, with a chief position heading each department.

These structures met the needs of their time, establishing reporting lines and headcount allocations around departmental boundaries, and generating organograms that depicted the company in a rigid, top-down view. In an era of stability and predictability, this approach worked. But the world of work has changed and so must our approach to HR organizational design.Today‚Äôs enterprises are shifting toward role-driven and increasingly skills-based models that foster agility, transparency, and a tighter alignment between workforce capabilities and business strategies that continuously adapt to changing business realities.

Yet many organizations still hold on to outdated ways of working in HR org design, forcing current needs into legacy concepts within today‚Äôs modern systems like SAP SuccessFactors. The consequence is unnecessary complexity, configurations that diverge from modern leading practices, limited use of standard features, and - most importantly - a missed opportunity to embrace a future-proof design philosophy.

This blog explores why it‚Äôs time to let go of legacy concepts, why positions, roles and skills should form the backbone of modern HR org design, and how to approach this shift in practice, for example when preparing for a SAP SuccessFactors implementation.

Clarifying the purpose of an HR organizational structure

Before rethinking how to best reflect your organization in a new HRIS system like SAP SuccessFactors, it‚Äôs important to step back from systems for a moment, and answer the question: what business purposes should an organizational structure serve today? At its core, it should enable:

 


Clarity of accountability: define who manages whom, and where primary supervisory responsibilities are placed. 

Functional identity: making it clear which teams or units serve which purpose in the enterprise

Operational transparency: providing senior leaders and employees visibility into how teams are grouped and connected from a workforce perspective.

Strategic adaptability: supporting planning, restructuring, and workforce reallocation when business priorities shift.

Communication and community: offering employees a sense of belonging to a recognized team or function.

 


These needs are universal, but the way they are fulfilled in HR context is fundamentally changing.

Adapting the workforce and how their skills are applied to meet shifting business needs must now be front and center. Today, organizational entities are best understood as groups of people with certain skills brought together to deliver a specific functional capability or set of capabilities to drive a certain outcome. In this sense, HR structures are less about static boxes, job titles and formal education, more about how people are grouped, managed and equiped to take on evolving tasks. Drawing strict lines around these groups, in the form of departments should in that sense become less relevant; in fact, trying to maintain departments in lockstep with every operational change, introduces unnecessary complexity and creates significant maintenance overhead.

Translating HR business needs into modern org design principles

If we take today‚Äôs HR business requirements seriously, certain organizational design principles emerge. These principles build on the distinction between functional groupings, positions, jobs, roles, and skills, each serving a different purpose in how organizations are structured and how work gets done:

  1. Anchor HR org design in business clarity, not legacy habits.
    When transitioning to a new system like SAP SuccessFactors, revisit the true, forward-looking business purposes of organizational structures and translate them into modern concepts and system design. Too often, legacy constructs such as those from SAP HCM OM are taken for granted as ‚Äúbusiness requirements‚Äù for the new system, without recognizing that they were originally also solution design choices and not carved-in-rock business necessities.
  2. Separate functional and operational dimensions.
    Functional groupings define how people and positions are organized around a shared mission or business purpose (e.g., a product line, sales organization, services, or center of expertise). Labels might change over time, but in essence they tend to be stable entities, providing continuity and identity over time. Typically these groupings are reflected in the Company Structure. Operational structures, on the other hand, determine how people are grouped to execute the work and define who manages whom. These structures are dynamic, shifting as teams, reporting lines, and spans of control evolve with business needs. This is typically reflected in the People Org Chart, based on people holding certain positions.
  3. Keep HR reporting lines position-driven.
    A position represents a unique "seat" in the structure, tied to a specific line manager and place in the hierarchy. Using a position-to-position hierarchy as the single source of truth for primary reporting lines, ensures clarity and consistency in how these are defined and maintained. This hierarchy should drive all core HR processes, from approvals and workflow routing to role-based permissions and HR analytics. Other attributes such as Business Units, Divisions and Departments are supporting elements in processing and reporting, but they should not replace the position hierarchy as the backbone of managerial relationships.
  4. Keep HR and Financial structures distinct.
    HR organizational design should focus on people management, functional identity, and workforce capabilities, while financial structures (such as cost centers or profit centers) serve budgeting, accounting, and financial control purposes. The two dimensions serve very different business needs, should not be forced into a single hierarchy, nor should the one dictate the other. Instead, it should be sufficient to connect them through clear integration points, for example, by linking positions or employees to cost centers so that workforce data can inform financial planning without constraining HR structures and the other way around.
  5. Define jobs as the employment anchor.
    A job defines what a person is formally hired into, capturing employment expectations, qualifications, pay structures, and key traits. It provides stability and consistency for HR processes such as recruiting, compensation, compliance, and career frameworks. However, jobs are not meant to dictate the actual, ever-evolving work carried out to achieve specific business outcomes. Instead, they serve as a stable reference point that ensures fairness and comparibility, while leaving flexibility to roles and skills to define what work is performed in practice.
  6. Use a role concept to reflect the work actually performed.
    A role represents a set of logically grouped capabilities and defines what a person executing on that role is expected to do in practice within a functional entity, in conjuntion and collaboration with other roles in the same context. One individual may execute multiple roles depending on projects and business needs (e.g., Functional Consultant, Solution Architect, Project Manager or Business Manager). Roles should be reflected in compentency models and skills taxonomies and provide the ultimate flexibility to react to changing needs and are the bridge to a skills-based view.
  7. Leverage skills as the adaptive layer.
    Skills cut across jobs, roles, and positions. They describe the actual capabilities people bring, and they enable operational workforce planning, project staffing, career development, and skill gap closure strategies, independently from the org structure. In modern organizations, these skills have become the true currency of agility, enabling companies to dynamically match talent with work as needs evolve. Skills taxonomies provide the framework to make this real.
  8. Support advanced needs with dedicated tools.
    Scenario planning, reorganizations, and rich visualizations should be supported through dedicated HR planning and analytics tools, like SAP Workforce Planning and Analytics, rather than forcing complexity and customization into the core EC  model. This keeps the foundation lean and aligned with clean-core principles.

Building for the future

Modern HR org design is about agility, clarity, and purpose, and it continues to evolve. By letting positions drive HR reporting lines, keeping the functional structure lean and aligned with real business needs, and leveraging roles and skills as the true connectors between people and work, organizations can simplify their structures while enhancing transparency and adaptability.

Looking ahead, the evolution does not stop here. Many organizations are experimenting with dynamic teams, temporary or cross-functional groups formed around specific business outcomes and dissolved once those outcomes are achieved. Dynamic teams build on the same foundation: positions provide the reporting anchor, jobs define the employment context, roles capture the contributions people make, and skills determine the best fit between talent and work. By embedding team formation in this model, enterprises can embrace agility and innovation without creating parallel hierarchies or adding unnecessary complexity to the core structure.

The result is a design philosophy that not only aligns with modern HR systems such as SuccessFactors but also equips the business to adapt and thrive in a world where change is constant and skills are the true currency of success.

Curious about how these concepts translate into your own SAP SuccessFactors environment?  SAP Services can help!

Josephine Damen, HR Business Architect
HR Innovation and Transformation
Adoption Services Center, SAP SuccesFactors HCM
e-mail: saphit@sap.com

entry.title: What's New in SAP BTP - Q3 2025
entry.content:
This third quarter brought some helpful innovation highlights for SAP Business Technology Platform, that we‚Äôre excited to share with you! The Q3 Innobytes demonstrate the progress we made in SAP BTP over the last months. Check out the video below and explore the latest features in Application Development, Joule and more. Enjoy watching!

 

App Dev Highlights

AI-powered Capabilities in SAP Build Work Zone

In the first demo, three new AI capabilities in SAP Build Work Zone are demonstrated to help you work smarter and more efficiently.

With AI Summarization, you can create a concise summary of long documents within seconds. Simply find the content in your workspace and click Summarize to save time and work smarter.

To make engaging with content easier, you can access AI Comment Generation via the AI icon to generate contextual comments, helping respond quickly and intelligently. 

To support content creation, the AI Text Generation helps with drafting an introduction or brainstorming ideas. In the workspace editor, you can ask AI to generate Text and let it support your experience in the SAP Build Work Zone.  

Watch the demo starting at 00:09 to see these innovations in action.

Learn more

  • Blog Post SAP Build Work Zone
  • SAP Build Work Zone
  •  SAP Community

 

Skill Builder in Joule General Availability

Welcome to Joule Studio, a powerful tool that enables you to create intelligent AI agents and custom-built Joule Skills based on your specific business needs.

The creation of Joule Studio‚Äôs AI agent is seamlessly integrated with SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), leveraging its robust security, scalability, and connectivity to SAP systems for maximum efficiency. In this demo, a new Joule Skill is created that automates the workflow of the badge printing process. It automatically generates and prints employee badges by integrating Joule Studio with the SAP HR database, and everything you need for this process is in one place.

Start the demo at 01:51 to get more insights.

Learn more

  • Get Started with Joule Studio
  • Detailed Tutorial
  • SAP Community Blog Page

 

Downtime-Optimized Upgrades for SAP BTP ABAP Environment

SAP BTP ABAP Environment now uses blue-green-fashioned lifecycle management to minimize the downtime during hotfixes and version upgrades.

A recent update demonstrates that switching to a new runtime takes only seconds, with release upgrades targeting about 30 minutes. This innovation aims to make the process more transparent, aligning with downtime more efficiently. With this improvement, we are minimizing downtime and optimizing upgrades! 

This demo uses an example to highlight this innovation further (starting at 03:15).

Learn more

  • SAP BTP ABAP Environment ‚Äì Maintenance Windows and Major Upgrade Windows in 2025

 

Integration

AI Adapter in SAP Integration Suite

In August, we released an AI adapter for Cloud Integration capability of the SAP Integration Suite on the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).

Available as part of the Standard plan and above, it allows integration flows to interact with Large Language Models, adding AI directly into the integration at runtime. In this demo iflow, a product review is analyzed with OpenAI to enrich them with customer sentiment. This example shows the detection of a negative sentiment in a product review through GPT-5. The adapter is available now for you to try.

Watch this part (starting at 04:29) to get more insights.

Learn more

  • AI Adapter Blog Post
  • AI Adapter on SAP Business Accelerator Hub

 

Data & Analytics

SQL Generation for SAP HANA in Joule

In SAP Build Code, Joule can now automatically generate SAP HANA SQL based on natural language prompts.

You can either execute it directly within the Joule panel or you can copy the SQL command into the SQL Console to perform additional operations or refinements. This integration streamlines workflows, boosts productivity, and reduces errors, eliminating manual coding and tool switching.

This is how it‚Äôs done:

  1. Enable SQL generation using object definitions in your workspace‚Äôs settings
  2. Navigate to your Joule extension and select the command type HANA SQL
  3. Type your Natural Language Prompt ‚Äì Joule will then generate and execute the SQL for you
  4. Execute or add operations or refinements to the results

See these steps in action (starting at 05:57).

Learn more

  • Generate SQL from Natural Language using Joule

 

Cross

Modifiable Transport Requests

SAP Cloud Transport Management Service now supports Modifiable Transport Requests, allowing you to test and adjust transport requests in safe test nodes before releasing them to production.

This is how it works:

  1. Create a Modifiable Transport Request with the Create button.
  2. When opening the request, see the Tracking tab that shows the transport landscape and is now open for changes.
  3. Add content to the request and click the Test button to import directly or later and freely add or remove content.
  4. Release the request when testing is completed.

This flexible approach enables adding, removing, or redeploying content as needed, ensuring higher quality and safer deployments. Automation and Integration with other SAP BTP services are planned, so stay tuned for more to come.

To see this demo in action, watch the video (starting at 07:36).

Learn more

  • Modifiable Transport Request Blog Post

 

Cross (Cloud ALM)

Change Point Detection for Custom BTP Apps in SAP Cloud ALM

Running custom apps on SAP BTP embraces Cloud Flexibility with the Clean Core Principle. With the SAP Cloud ALM for Operations, you can monitor SAP and non-SAP applications end-to-end. This feature ensures business continuity and operational efficiency.

Real User Monitoring gives you clear insights into usage by tracking executions, performance, and response times all in one interface. 

If the performance suddenly shifts, Change Point Detection identifies unusual patterns in the performance compared to historical trends. You can then directly navigate to the respective request and even receive alerts or emails when a change point is detected. This helps quick investigation of the issue and ensures smooth operations.

This new feature is highlighted (starting at 08:52).

Learn more

  • SAP Cloud ALM for Operations Expert Portal
  • SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide (Github)
  • Join us for TechEd:
  • CS101 | Discover SAP Cloud ALM for operations in action
  • CS261 | Monitoring a custom SAP BTP application with SAP Cloud ALM for operations

 

Share your thoughts 

These videos are for YOU, and we would love to hear your impressions. How do you like the video? How can we improve the upcoming videos? Please share your feedback by liking this post or leaving a comment below.

Thank you for your support and happy viewing, sharing, and enjoying!

You Might Also Be Interested In

  • SAP BTP Garage: monthly LIVE webinar with hands-on use case walkthroughs and demos.
  • Unlocking SAP BTP: monthly podcast covering all things SAP BTP.

entry.title: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio ‚Äî Part 3 (3)
entry.content:
üöÄ Series Overview: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio

  • Part 1 ‚Äî Building the Custom AI Agent Backend
  • Part 2 (1) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Environment & Containerization)
  • Part 2 (2) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Deployment & Testing)
  • Part 3 (1) ‚Äî Setting Up Joule Studio Connection (Destination & Environment)
  • Part 3 (2) ‚Äî Creating a Joule Skill (Design & Release)
  • Part 3 (3) ‚Äî Testing and Sharing on Work Zone

 

Part 3 (3) ‚Äî Testing and Sharing the skill on Work Zone

In the previous part, we designed a CustomAgent Skill that links your AI Core backend actions and defines how Joule interprets user inputs. Now, it‚Äôs time to test it live, right inside Joule Chat Interface, and finally share it with your organization‚Äôs via Work Zone, so that others can access your agent.

By the end of this section, you will:

  • Test your Skill in Joule Chat Interface
  • share the Skill to Work Zone for organization-wide access

 

1. Test the Skill in Joule Chat interface

Once your Skill is released and deployed to the environment, it becomes available inside the Joule Chat interface.

Step 1. Launch Joule Chat Interface

Go to Control Tower ‚Üí select correct Environment ‚Üí More ‚Üí Joule ‚Üí Launch

This opens the Joule Chat interface for that specific environment.

Step 2. Start Conversation

You can start chatting naturally by sending any message, Joule will automatically detect the appropriate Skill based on your setup.

 

In this example, we'll start the conversation using an activation phrase (e.g., /CustomAgent) to trigger the Skill explicitly based on how we set from skill description in this post. This approach helps ensure the correct Skill is activated during testing.

Example. Triggering the Skill and maintaining a continuous agentic flow

The example below illustrate how the CustomAgent Skill is triggered and how the agentic workflow executes step by step. Here, the backend queries SAP HANA Cloud to retrieve real-time stock data before generating a natural-language summary response.

Joule detects the message and routes it to the CustomAgent Skill (triggered by /CustomAgent). This skill is linked to your backend endpoint deployed on SAP AI Core, which handles the reasoning and multi-step action execution. 

 

üîç  How the Agentic Flow Executes

  1. Planner Stage (/v2/plan) : The backend receives the request and generates a plan. Example from the chat,
    • Generate SQL query to check current stock level for 'Wireless Mouse' product.
    • Execute the generated SQL query to get current stock level.
    • Provide a clear response about the available stock quantity.
  2. Action Graph Creation (/v2/action-graph) : The agent converts the plan into series of executable steps in LangGraph.
  3. Execution Stage (/v2/start-execution) : The actions are executed in order (querying stock, formatting a reply, etc.).
  4. Response Delivery (/v2/continue-execution) : The final message is sent back to Joule, which displays the result in the chat.

Each stage is visible in the conversation window as we designed Joule Skill in the previous post, allowing user to trace the full reasoning process step by step.

 

‚ôæ  Maintaining a Continuous Conversation

To maintain continuity between messages, the system uses a unique converation_id that is shared between Joule and your backend. 

When a message is sent to the Joule, Joule parses the conversation_id from the user input.

On the backend side (AI Core), it either:

  • uses an existing conversation_id provide by the user and parsed by Joule ‚Äî to continue an ongoing conversation
  • generates a new one if nothing is provided ‚Äî to start a new conversation   

This design ensures that every conversation session can be explicitly tracked and resumed. 

The example below show how the agent continues the same conversation seamlessly using the shared conversation_id.

 

Because Joule parsed and passed the same converstaion_id (session-b31e574a) from the previous turn, the backend recognized that the new message belonged to the same session. As a result, the agent was able to reference the previous HANA query result and compose a follow-up order email template ‚Äî without the user needing to restate any context.

 

üí¨  Extending the Flow to External Tools

In the next step, the same converstaion_id (session-b31e574a) was used again ‚Äî this time to send the previously composed order email through Gmail integration.

The following example shows how the same agentic flow extends beyond Joule to interact with an external tool like Gmail.

Here, the backend reused the prior plan and template ‚Äî demonstrating how multi-step reasoning, enterprise data retrieval, and third-party API execution can all occur within a single continuous conversation inside Joule.

 

2. Share the Skill to Work Zone

Once your Skill is tested and working as expected, you can share it to Work Zone so that other users in your organization can access it. This is done by sharing the Joule capabilities from your Control Tower > Environments.

  • Go to Control Tower ‚Üí Environments ‚Üí Select your Environment
  • Navigate to the Joule tab at the top
  • Click the gear icon (‚öôÔ∏è) next to your Joule environment

 

Now you can share your Skill with specific users or user groups in your organization.
This process is well explained in the following SAP Community post: Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build ‚Äì Part 4: Managing Access to Custom Joule Skills 

 

Wrapping Up the Series

With this final part, you‚Äôve completed the Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio series.

You now have:

  • A Flask-based agentic backend running on SAP AI Core
  • A Skill in Joule Studio that connects to it through Actions
  • A live conversational interface integrated into SAP Work Zone

Through this setup, you‚Äôve built an enterprise-ready agentic chatbot ‚Äî capable of reasoning over enterprise data, executing dynamic multi-step actions, and integrating securely with external tools inside your organization.

This concludes the series on building an end-to-end Custom Agentic Chatbot. We hope this walkthrough helps you design, deploy, and scale your own AI agent workflows with confidence using SAP AI Core and Joule Studio. üöÄ

entry.title: How to create custom communication scenarios in S4H Public Cloud Dev Tenant ?
entry.content:
Dear Community,

We have developed OData services directly on the S/4HANA Public Cloud development tenant and created a UI in BAS to consume these services (using the Developer Extensibility approach). During testing in BAS, we need to create custom communication scenarios; however, the option to create custom communication scenarios in the development tenant is currently greyed out/disabled.

Based on the information provided in SAP Note 2486898, to enable the creation of custom communication scenarios, we need to activate Key User Extensibility using the Extensibility Settings app. However, when we attempt to do this in the development tenant, the system displays a message indicating that Key User Extensibility is disabled in the development tenant and that the Customizing tenant should be used instead.

In the Customizing tenant, Key User Extensibility is enabled, and we are able to create communication scenarios. However, we cannot transport the OData services to the Customizing tenant without first testing them in the Development tenant.

Is there a way to test the services in BAS while connecting directly to the Development tenant?

Thank you!

Regards,

Karthik

entry.title: New Cloudification Repository Viewer for Clean Core Governance and Development
entry.content:
This blog is meant to be a quick read ‚Äî the idea is to cover the new Clean Core Cloudification Repository Viewer (CRV) features over your morning coffee‚òï, and kick off a new day of your SAP Clean Core journey.

I am an SAP Clean Core and Extensibility Lifecycle consultant, and I have supported many RISE with SAP customers in establishing Clean Core governance models, solution standardization boards (SSB), and extensibility development guidelines. Through various concrete use cases, I have gained extensive hands-on experience.

From the perspective of Clean Core development and governance, having a unified API repository is of critical importance.

After SAP released the Clean Core Extensibility White Paper and the New Clean Core Level concept, the Cloudification Repository Viewer has now also been updated with a new version, and I am very excited to share its new features with you right away.

SAP Product

In the filter bar, we will see the SAP Products: SAP Cloud ERP, SAP Cloud ERP Private, and SAP BTP ABAP Environment. If the system is SAP Cloud ERP Private, we select SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Release

After selecting SAP Cloud ERP Private, we will then see a Release option. Here, we can choose the Cloud ERP release version and the corresponding SP level. It is worth noting that as the Cloud ERP evolves, the number of available APIs is steadily increasing.

Partner Namespace

One particularly exciting development is the introduction of the ‚ÄúPartner Namespace.‚Äù With SAP Clean Core‚Äôs certification for partners, certified partners are now able to publish released APIs as well. In my view, this represents a significant step forward for the entire extensibility ecosystem.

State

Next is the ‚ÄúState‚Äù field, which is the most interesting part because the Clean Core levels are ‚Äúhidden‚Äù here. This allows us to easily and clearly identify whether an API is categorized as Level A, B, C, or D.

Object Type / Software Component / Application Component

As in the previous version, filtering objects by Object Type, Software Component, or Application Component is also supported.

Label

Within the final Label field, additional details are available ‚Äî for instance, APIs marked as ‚Äútransactional-consistent‚Äù are suitable for use in RAP-based applications.

To summarize:

  1. The new CRV interface has a clearer layout ‚Äî first select the Cloud ERP version, then the release version, and then the state/level, which makes the process straightforward.
  2. Released APIs, classic APIs, not-to-be-released APIs, and NO APIs can be presented in a single view, distinguished and filtered by State.
  3. Clean Core levels are shown explicitly, which makes identifying the classification of each API much simpler.
  4. The Clean Core API framework is becoming increasingly standardized, with more and more Level A and B APIs available.
  5. Partner APIs that have been certified are also being included, further expanding the extensibility ecosystem.
  6. Object Type, Software Component, Application Component, and Label are still retained.

With the release of the new CRV version, I‚Äôm delighted to have another handy tool added to my Clean Core governance and extensibility development arsenal.

Of course, a single weapon is not enough ‚Äî we also need to leverage all the Clean Core tools to deliver a true combination punch:

For Clean Core extensibility White paper, please refer to Whitepaper 

For Clean Core ATC Checks, please refer to note 3565942

For Clean Core frameworks, technologies and development patterns, please refer to note 3578329

For SAP Build on BTP, please refer to SAP Build

For Clean Core Extensibility Guide, please refer to Extensibility Guide

Re-evaluation in Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) is triggered either by scheduling the application job F4277 ‚Äì Run Revenue Recognition - Projects or by using the Revalue function within the monitoring app F4767 ‚Äì Event-Based Revenue Recognition - Projects.

entry.title: Introducing SAP Fiori for Android/iOS 25.8: Innovative Enhancements for Android and iOS
entry.content:
SAP Fiori continues to advance its technological offerings with the release of SAP BTP SDK version 25.8, featuring exciting updates for both Android and iOS. This release introduces a suite of new capabilities as well as upgrades to current features, enhancing user experiences on business apps.

New in SAP Fiori for Android 25.8

In the following section, we‚Äôll give you a brief overview about everything that‚Äôs new in SAP Fiori for Android 25.8.

Circular In-Place Progress Indicator

The circular in-place progress indicator displays the status of ongoing processes when loading is initiated by a button. An indicator within the button shows the loading state. The progress indicator has been enhanced to allow customization of the icon button so that once loading is finished, the icon button can be changed to a different icon.

For more information, check out the Circular Progress Indicator article in the SAP Fiori for Android design guidelines.

Object cell with a circular progress indicator

Illustrated Message

The illustrated message component, which helps communicate empty, error, and success states through a combination of engaging illustrations, solution-oriented messages, and a conversational tone, has been updated with new illustration assets.

To learn more about this component, refer to Illustrated Message.

Illustrated message with the new ‚Äúempty task‚Äù illustration

Native File Viewer

The native file viewer, which allows users to preview files, now supports viewing password-protected PDFs by prompting them to enter a password in a dialog before the file is displayed, expanding accessibility and document control within apps.

For more information, check out Native File Viewer.

Password-protected PDF files in native file viewer

Picker Form Cell

The picker form cell, used for making date and time-based selections, is now available for Jetpack Compose.

See Date and Time Picker Form Cell for more information.

Date picker form cell with Horizon tonal color option

Stepper Form Cell

The stepper form cell and the nested stepper control, which allow users to incrementally increase or decrease a select value, are now available for Jetpack Compose.

Check out the Stepper Form Cell guideline article to learn more.

Stepper form cell in horizontal layout (top) and vertical layout (bottom)

Text Input Form Cell

Text input form cells have been enhanced to provide currency support, allowing users to enter currency values in single property form cells.  The form cells now feature ISO codes  that automatically format the text input with the corresponding currency symbol.

For more information, refer to Text Inputs.

‚ÄÉ

New in SAP Fiori for iOS 25.8

Check out what's new in SAP Fiori for Android 25.8. 

Illustrated Message

Just like the Android equivalent, the illustrated message component has been updated with new illustration assets to help communicate empty, error, and success states with engaging illustrations.

Learn more about this component in the Illustrated Message SAP Fiori for iOS guideline article.

Illustrated message in different containers

Modals and Sheets

We have added new guideline articles for modality and sheets that cover all types of modals and sheets, including but not limited to full-screen modals, non-modal sheets, action sheets, popovers, and form sheets.

For more information, refer to Modality and Sheets.

Modal sheet‚ÄÉ

Pickers

The date range picker is now supported as a picker form cell, enabling the triggering of the date range selection component.

Take a look at the Pickers guideline article for more information.‚ÄÉ

Date range picker

Text Inputs

Text inputs now come with currency support via a new view modifier, enabling display of the ISO code in the text input label, showing the currency symbol after editing, and applying localized formatting using native Apple APIs and formatters.

Check out Text Inputs to view more details.

Text input - single property form cell with currency field support

 

Resources

Design Guidelines

A detailed documentation on component anatomy, behavior, and interactions allows you to use components that match your use case. Crosslinks to Google‚Äôs Material Design Guidelines for Android and Apple‚Äôs Human Interface Guidelines for iOS, as well as links to development documentation, help you navigate to these resources. Additionally, you can find a feedback function on each guideline article that allows you to provide feedback.

SAP Fiori for Android Design Guidelines | SAP Fiori for iOS Design Guidelines

UI Kits for Figma

SAP Fiori for Android and iOS UIKit

With the updated SAP Fiori for Android and iOS Design Kits, it‚Äôs now easier than ever to use the latest components and patterns in your mobile design. By using the Design Kits, you can quickly create a consistent user experience that enables app implementations at scale.

SAP Fiori for Android 25.8 UI Kits | SAP Fiori for iOS 25.8 UI Kits

‚ÄÉ

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite - Operations - Landscape
entry.content:
Dear Community,

this blog provides practical insights into setting up a proper landscape for SAP Integration Suite.

Intention:

With the move to Integration Suite as middleware, customers will reach an early point at which they need to consider their future landscape setup. SAP provides many resources (such as the Reference Architecture, Discovery Center, Naming Conventions, Learning Journey, Considerations on the System Landscape for Integration when On-boarding into SAP Cloud Integration) to help them get started and become familiar with the new environment. Based on multiple customer ramp-ups, a clear picture is emerging of what a solid setup can look like.

Approach:

We collect the basic information required to run and operate Integration Suite properly. This includes a simple consideration of the account setup and the services we recommend for your integration landscape (such as Transport Management, SAP Cloud ALM, etc.).

Solution:

How many tenants (SAP BTP subaccounts) are needed for SAP Integration Suite to support such a landscape?

"A general rule of thumb is to align the landscape of the SAP Integration Suite with the primary business system in your architecture."

However, the decision between a 2-tier or 3-tier landscape for SAP Integration Suite also depends on various organizational and functional factors:

  • A 2-tier landscape is suitable for simpler scenarios where mostly preconfigured content is used.
  • A 3-tier landscape is suitable for more complex environments with existing multi-tier on-premise systems and extended quality assurance requirements.

What about the sizing of Integration Suite in comparison to PI/PO?

As of now, the number of messages is the primary factor influencing cost. Other aspects ‚Äî such as sizing ‚Äî do not affect the price. Scaling is handled entirely by SAP, and there are some internal value sets defined. SAP Cloud Integration generally scales well (scale up/out), provided that the integration flows are designed according to the design guidelines. For Edge Integration Cell, the concept is different, as the infrastructure is managed in the customer's private landscape. Therefore, planned sizing should be taken into consideration.

Are there differences between DEV, Test, and Prod regarding message calculation? What should we take into consideration?

SAP Integration Suite - Message Metric Definition serves as our source of truth for message calculation in SAP Integration Suite. It also includes the following important information: ‚ÄúThere is no concept of development, test, and production landscapes in SAP Integration Suite. Messages on all tenants are metered based on the description in this note.‚Äù

What do we need to start with our Integration Suite setup? 

As a very basic setup, we would take the Integration Suite subscrription in consideration. 

Means According to question 1. We are goging to deploy and rollout our Landscape as per our needs. 

The Integration Suite Subaccount should follow a specific Nameinc Convetion: 

Is there anything else i need to take in Consideration? 

Beyond the Integration Suite we recommend to take the following further Services also in consideation. 

By default, you can leverage SAP'S Default IDP for User Accces and Role Managemenet. Users which should work in Integration Suite Env. can get pre defined rolles assigend. Identity and User Management. 

SAP Cloud transport Management for your Basic Landscape and transport Secenarios in Integration Suite. Beside a file based manual appraoch you can, transport with Cloud Transport Managemenet in an at least proper way your contant across your landscape. Important: If you want to leverage Cloud Tranport Managemenet in combination with Cloud ALM The Cloud Transport Managemenet Service should not be setup withhin the same account of Cloud ALM (there are some technical relations, which could result in some issues) 

For Monitoring aspects take Cloud ALM in consideration. The Integration and Exceaption Monitoroing for the Cloud Integration part of Integration Suite you can cover already with minimum effort an overall Monitoring concept f√ºr your hybrid Integration landscape. As Cloud ALM is basically free for Customer, you should use this as one of your key considerations. 

Are there diffrences between Data Centers to run Integration Suite ? 

I want to use AI feautues? 

Can I start with 2 Tier Landscape and increase the Number to 3 and more Tennats aferwards ? 

Yes, for at least a proper diffrentation between DEV/QS and Prod you can start with the small setup. There are multiple 

CI/CD concept for Integration Suite - parallel Development of Integration Flows?

SAP provides an concept called "Pipeline- Concpet" which could maybe help in specific usecases to cover parallel rollout etc.

entry.title: How to Check Fiori Apps Related Authorization Object Mass
entry.content:
Introduction

In SAP implementations, understanding the underlying authorization objects associated with each app is crucial for secure and compliant access management. However, manually identifying these objects for multiple apps can be time-consuming and error-prone. This article presents a structured approach to mass-check authorization objects related to Fiori apps using backend SAP tables and metadata.

Objective

To extract and analyze the authorization objects linked to multiple Fiori apps by leveraging the relationship between Fiori App IDs, OData services, and SAP authorization tables.



Step-by-Step Process

1. Extract Fiori App ID ‚Äì OData Service Mapping

Start by retrieving the mapping between Fiori App IDs and their corresponding OData services. This can be done using the SAP Fiori Apps Library or via internal documentation if available.

Each Fiori app typically has one or more OData services that it consumes. This mapping is essential for tracing the backend logic and authorization.

2. Match OData Services with Authorization Hashes (Table: USOBHASH)

Once you have the list of OData services, use the USOBHASH table to find the corresponding hash values. These hash values represent the technical linkage between services and their authorization metadata.

  • Key Fields:
    • PGMID (usually 'R3TR')
    • OBJECT (e.g., 'IWSG' for OData services)
    • OBJ_NAME (OData service name)
    • HASH (authorization hash)

This step helps you identify which hash is associated with each OData service.

3. Retrieve Authorization Objects via Hash (Table: USOBTC)

Using the hash values obtained from USOBHASH, query the USOBTC table to extract the actual authorization objects.

  • Key Fields:
    • HASH
    • AUTH_OBJ (e.g., S_SERVICE, S_RFC, etc.)

This table provides the list of authorization objects that are checked when the corresponding OData service is executed.

Example Workflow

Let‚Äôs say you want to analyze the authorization objects for a set of Fiori apps used in the Procurement module:

  1. Extract App IDs and OData services from the Fiori Apps Library.
  2. Query USOBHASH to get the hash values for each OData service.
  3. Use those hash values to query USOBTC and retrieve the related authorization objects.
  4. Compile the results into a report (e.g., Excel or JSON) for further analysis or role design.

Note: Some Fiori applications do not have an odata service. Therefore, those with a transaction code are already found in USOBTC as transaction codes. For others, e.g., webdynpro applications, I couldn't find a quick method. I added the catalog to the role, got the hash code, and manually placed it in an Excel file. Only 5 out of 300 Fiori applications worked this way.

Conclusion

By leveraging the relationship between Fiori App IDs, OData services, and SAP authorization tables (USOBHASH, USOBTC), consultants and security teams can efficiently perform mass analysis of authorization objects. This method supports better role design, compliance audits, and secure Fiori app deployments.

entry.title: ALMathon 2025 - abat Resource Planning Suite: Extending SAP Cloud ALM with a comprehensive solution
entry.content:
Introduction

Nowadays it becomes more and more difficult to manage a project while allocate resources effectively . Therefore capacity planning remains a critical challenge for organizations using SAP solutions. Inefficient resource allocation can lead to project delays, increased costs and decreased productivity. As part of the ALMathon 2025, we have developed a comprehensive extension to SAP Cloud ALM that addresses these pain points through a suite of integrated resource planning applications.

The Challenge

Project managers and team leads using SAP Cloud ALM often struggle with several key questions

  • How do we identify over-utilized or under-utilized team members?
  • How can we proactively detect capacity issues before they impact project timelines?
  • What‚Äôs the most efficient way to assign tasks to team members based on their availability?
  • How do we factor in planned absences when scheduling project work?

These challenges can significantly hinder project success and overall organizational efficiency.

Our Solution

Our Resource Planning Suite extends SAP Cloud ALM capabilities by providing a holistic approach to resource management across projects. This suite enhances visibility and enables data-driven decision-making, ensuring that resources are allocated efficiently and effectively. Key features include a real-time resource utilization tracking, predictive capacity planning and intelligent task assignment based on team member availability and skills.

Suite Components

Our comprehensive solution consists of three interconnected applications designed to address different aspects of resource planning while maintaining a unified data model and user experience. These applications read core data from SAP Cloud ALM and extend it with additional information, creating a seamless and integrated resource planning environment. IT includes:

  • Project Management: Displays general project data, assigned employees and tasks
  • Employee Management: Provides detailed employee data, assigned tasks and projects as well as individual utilization, skills and absences.
  • Task Management: Shows all tasks with effort, time and needed skill data, their corresponding projects and assigned employees

Together, these applications form a cohesive system that enhances visibility, enables data-driven decision making and ensures consistent user experience. In the following sections we will delve into the specifics of each application and how they contribute to effective resource planning.

Project Management

The foundation of our suite begins with direct integration to Cloud ALM project data. This component creates a seamless bridge between the core functionality of Cloud ALM and resource planning capabilities, allowing project managers to view all active projects, their status, and associated resources in a unified interface without redundant data entry or synchronization issues. With this integration, project managers can easily track project progress, identify resource bottlenecks and make informed decisions to optimize resource allocation. In this view we can directly assign new employees with the planned time for the project and its utilization. So it won‚Äôt be possible to assign tasks for 40 hours a week, if the employee is just assigned for 50%.

Employee Management

Building upon the project foundation, the employee management module serves as a centralized repository for all resource information. Managers can track skills, competencies, allocation percentages, current utilization rates, role assignments, and historical project performance. This module provides immediate visibility into which team members are overallocated or have capacity for additional work, enabling proactive resource balancing across the organization. Perhaps the most innovative aspect of our solution is the integrated absence management system that completes the resource planning picture. Employees can self-report planned absences such as vacation or training time, the system recalculates available capacity in real-time This allows project timelines to be adjusted based on actual resource availability, preventing unrealistic commitments and ensuring that projects stay on track.

Task Management

The task management application extends the functionality further by offering an intuitive interface for visualizing all tasks across projects, matching tasks to employees based on skills and availability, tracking completion status with effort estimates, and identifying bottlenecks in resource allocation. This ensures that work is distributed optimally and provides early warning when resource constraints might impact deliverables.

Additionally, there are also checks implemented to prevent overutilization of employee capacities. This means that if an employee is already full allocated, the system will not allow to assign additional tasks, ensuring that no one is overburdened.

Upcoming: Sprint Planning & Timeboxing

For organizations employing agile methodologies, our sprint planning component integrates with the task management system to enable drag-and-drop assignment of tasks to sprints, capacity visualization per sprint, workload balancing across iterations, and early detection of overcommitment. This creates a clear connection between resource capacity and delivery commitments within defined timeboxes. For example project managers can easily assigntasks to specific sprints and visualize the capacity of each sprint, ensuring that no sprint is overloaded.

Technical Implementation

Our solution leverages SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) as the primary development framework, providing a robust and extensible foundation for the entire suite. We‚Äôve designed a unified data model that aligns with SAP best practices while extending key entities to support enhanced resource planning capabilities.

  • Integration Architecture: The technical implementation focuses on seamless connectivity with SAP Cloud ALM through established APIs. This ensures consistent data exchange without duplication and maintains the integrity of the system of record while extending its functionality. Our architecture follows SAP‚Äôs recommended patterns for cloud extensions, making it maintainable and upgrade-compatible.
  • User Experience Design: The user interfaces across all applications in the suite follow SAP Fiori design guidelines, ensuring a consistent and intuitive experience that minimizes training requirements. We‚Äôve implemented responsive designs that work across devices, enabling resource management from anywhere.
  • Performance Optimization: Given the data-intensive nature of resource planning across multiple projects, we‚Äôve implemented optimized database queries to ensure rapid response times even when analyzing complex resource allocation scenarios. The application maintains performance even when processing large volumes of task and resource data.
  • Security & Compliance: Our implementation adheres to SAP‚Äôs security recommendations, with appropriate role-based access controls ensuring that sensitive resource and project data remains protected while still enabling the necessary visibility for effective planning. We‚Äôve maintained full auditability of resource allocation decisions to support compliance requirements.

Realized Benefits

Organizations implementing our Resource Planning Suite extension can expect:

  1. Increased transparency into resource utilization across projects
  2. Reduced administrative overhead through automation of capacity calculations
  3. Improved project delivery timelines due to early detection of resource constraints
  4. Enhanced employee satisfaction by preventing burnout from overallocation
  5. Better strategic planning capabilities with improved resource forecasting

Conclusion

By extending SAP Cloud ALM with our Resource Planning Suite, organizations gain powerful tools to optimize their most valuable assets - their people. The integrated approach ensures that project managers have complete visibility into capacity challenges, can make informed decisions about task assignments, and ultimately deliver projects more successfully.

Our participation in the ALMathon has allowed us to address a critical gap in the project management lifecycle while leveraging SAP‚Äôs modern development frameworks. We look forward to continuing to enhance this solution based on user feedback and evolving project management practices.

entry.title: SAP EWM Transactions
entry.content:
SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) is a powerful solution designed to optimize complex warehouse processes. Whether you're managing inbound deliveries, outbound shipments, or internal stock movements, EWM provides a rich set of transaction codes (T-codes) to streamline operations.

In this blog, we‚Äôll explore the most essential EWM transaction codes categorized by business processes, helping you navigate the system with confidence.

üîπ Inbound Delivery Processing

Inbound processes are critical for receiving goods efficiently. Key T-codes include:

  • /SCWM/IDN ‚Äì Maintain Inbound Delivery Notification
  • /SCWM/PRDI ‚Äì Maintain Inbound Delivery
  • /SCWM/GRPE ‚Äì GR Preparation for External Procurement
  • /SCWM/GRPI ‚Äì GR Preparation for Production
  • /SCWM/UNLOAD ‚Äì Unload Goods
  • /SCWM/EGR ‚Äì Maintain Expected Goods Receipt

üîπ Outbound Delivery Processing

Outbound transactions ensure timely and accurate dispatch of goods:

  • /SCWM/ODR ‚Äì Maintain Outbound Delivery Request
  • /SCWM/PRDO ‚Äì Maintain Outbound Delivery Order
  • /SCWM/FD ‚Äì Final Delivery
  • /SCWM/LOAD ‚Äì Load Goods
  • /SCWM/SGI ‚Äì Post Goods Issue

üîπ Posting Changes & Internal Movements

These transactions help manage stock adjustments and transfers:

  • /SCWM/IM_DR ‚Äì Maintain Posting Change Request
  • /SCWM/IM_PC ‚Äì Maintain Posting Change
  • /SCWM/IM_ST ‚Äì Internal Stock Transfer
  • /SCWM/POST ‚Äì Make Posting Change

üîπ Warehouse Task & Order Processing

Warehouse tasks are the backbone of physical movements:

  • /SCWM/ADPROD ‚Äì Create Product Warehouse Task
  • /SCWM/TO_CONF ‚Äì Confirm Warehouse Task
  • /SCWM/TODLV_I ‚Äì Putaway WT for Inbound Delivery
  • /SCWM/TODLV_O ‚Äì Stock Removal for Outbound Delivery

üîπ Physical Inventory

Accurate inventory counts are vital for operational integrity:

  • /SCWM/PI_CREATE ‚Äì Create Physical Inventory Document
  • /SCWM/PI_COUNT ‚Äì Enter Count Results
  • /SCWM/DIFF_ANALYZER ‚Äì Analyze Differences
  • /SCWM/WM_ADJUST ‚Äì Post Differences to ERP

üîπ Quality Management

Ensure product quality through integrated QM processes:

  • /SCWM/VAS_I ‚Äì VAS in Goods Receipt
  • /SCWM/VAS_O ‚Äì VAS in Goods Issue
  • /SCWM/VASEXEC ‚Äì Confirm VAS Execution

üîπ Monitoring & Reporting

Stay on top of warehouse performance:

  • /SCWM/MON ‚Äì Warehouse Monitor
  • /SCWM/ERP_STOCKCHECK ‚Äì Compare ERP and EWM Stock
  • /SCWM/ACTLOG ‚Äì Activate Application Log

üîπ Other Useful Transactions

  • /SCWM/MAT1 ‚Äì Maintain Warehouse Product
  • /SCWM/PACKSPEC ‚Äì Maintain Packaging Specification
  • /SCWM/LS01 ‚Äì Create Storage Bin
  • /SCWM/SLOT ‚Äì Slot Products for Warehouse

üìå Tips for Navigating EWM Transactions

  • Use SE93 to explore transaction codes and their packages.
  • Use SE80 to browse transaction folders by package.
  • Refer to SAP Notes like 2524406 for mapping GUI transactions to Fiori apps.

‚úÖ Conclusion

Mastering these transaction codes empowers warehouse professionals to execute tasks efficiently, reduce errors, and improve overall logistics performance. Whether you're a functional consultant or a warehouse manager, understanding these T-codes is key to unlocking the full potential of SAP EWM.

Ref Link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/sewm/3354623031.html

entry.title: Global Alert Mechanism to Monitor iFlows in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
üìå Introduction

Monitoring integration flows (iFlows) in SAP Integration Suite is critical for ensuring business continuity and proactive issue resolution. While SAP provides standard monitoring tools, many organizations benefit from a global alert mechanism that sends real-time notifications when an iFlow fails or encounters an error.

In this blog, we‚Äôll walk through how to implement a global alert system using Groovy scripting, message properties, and the Mail Adapter to notify stakeholders with detailed error information and direct links to message monitoring.


Below is the image of the Integration Flow I created:

üéØObjective

To create a reusable alert mechanism that:

  • Captures error details from any iFlow.
  • Generates a direct link to the failed message in SAP Integration Suite.
  • Sends an HTML-formatted email with a clickable hyperlink to the monitoring dashboard.

üõ†Ô∏è Prerequisites

  • Access to SAP Integration Suite (Cloud Integration).
  • Basic knowledge of iFlow design and Groovy scripting.
  • Mail Adapter configured with SMTP settings.

Step 1: Set Up the Tenant Monitoring URL

Add a Content Modifier at the start of your iFlow to set the tenant‚Äôs monitoring URL as a property:

Property Name: TenantMoniURL
Value:

https://<your-tenant>.integrationsuite.cfapps.<region>.hana.ondemand.com

Step 2: Generate the Monitoring URL with Groovy

Add a Groovy Script step after the Content Modifier:

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;

def Message processData(Message message) {
def headers = message.getHeaders()
def properties = message.getProperties()

def messageId = headers.get("MessageId")
def tenantMoniURL = properties.get("TenantMoniURL")

def monitoringURL = "${tenantMoniURL}/shell/monitoring/Messages/%7B%22identifier%22%3A%22${messageId}%22%7D"
message.setProperty("MonitoringURL", monitoringURL)

return message
}

Step 3: Configure the Mail Adapter for HTML Alerts

Set the Mail Adapter body type to HTML and use this template:

Note:
Always ensure the Mail Adapter is set to HTML format, or the hyperlink will not render correctly.

Step 4: Test and Validate

  1. Trigger the iFlow (manually or via a test sender).
  2. Check your email for the alert.
  3. Click the hyperlink to verify it opens the correct message in SAP Integration Suite monitoring.

Main iFlow Alert Content modifier under Exception Subprocess:- 

Output Screen :

üîÑReusability

You can place this alert logic in a ProcessDirect-based reusable iFlow and call it from any other iFlow using an exception subprocess. This ensures centralized alerting and easier maintenance.

‚úÖBenefits

  • Real-time visibility into failed messages.
  • Direct access to message monitoring.
  • Reduces manual effort in tracking errors.
  • Improves operational efficiency and SLA compliance.

üìåConclusion

Implementing a global alert mechanism in SAP Integration Suite is a best practice for proactive monitoring and rapid issue resolution. By leveraging Groovy scripting and HTML-formatted emails, you can deliver rich, actionable alerts directly to your support team.

If you have any questions or insights, feel free to share your thoughts in the comments!

 @Souravraj_Maitra @Ankit_Kumar_Singh_02 @Swaita_Banerjee @Ankit_Kanungo_057

entry.title: SAP DRC - Unable to Submit Credit Note Due to Missing UUID of Original Invoice
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

We‚Äôre currently facing an error when submitting a credit note ‚Äî the system prompts that the ‚ÄúOriginal e-Invoice Reference Number is missing‚Äù, which refers to the missing UUID of the original invoice.

According to the SAP website here Creating and Submitting Electronic Customer Invoices to the Tax Authority | SAP Help Portal, it‚Äôs mentioned that when creating a source correction document through the Create Outgoing Invoices app, we should enter the internal document number of the original invoice in the HeaderText field under the header details. This should allow the system to automatically populate the IRBM unique identifier number and the internal document number of the original invoice in the XML file of the correction document.

However, in our case, the credit note isn‚Äôt pulling the IRBM unique identifier automatically, and it still needs to be entered manually.

Has anyone experienced this issue or found a solution? Appreciate any insights.

entry.title: SAP MDG: How to Grey Out Copy Button in ERP Vendor: Purchasing Organizations UIBB ?
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great üôÇ

Note 01: This blog does not include execution screenshots.
Note 02: The entire code was developed and validated in the SANDBOX system, with results meeting expectations.
Note 03: There are several ways; this blog is written about one of them.

Create customizing or enhance UIBB.

Standard Feeder Class: CL_BS_SP_GUIBB_PURCH_ORGS.

Create one custom class: ZCL_MDGS_GUIBB_PURCH_ORGS & do inherit above standard feeder class.

Now, utilize this method:  METHOD if_fpm_guibb_list~get_data.

Code:

CALL METHOD super->if_fpm_guibb_list~get_data
      EXPORTING
        iv_eventid                = iv_eventid
        it_selected_fields        = it_selected_fields
        iv_raised_by_own_ui       = iv_raised_by_own_ui
        iv_visible_rows           = iv_visible_rows
        iv_edit_mode              = iv_edit_mode
        io_extended_ctrl          = io_extended_ctrl
      IMPORTING
        et_messages               = et_messages
        ev_data_changed           = ev_data_changed
        ev_field_usage_changed    = ev_field_usage_changed
        ev_action_usage_changed   = ev_action_usage_changed
        ev_selected_lines_changed = ev_selected_lines_changed
        ev_dnd_attr_changed       = ev_dnd_attr_changed
        eo_itab_change_log        = eo_itab_change_log
      CHANGING
        ct_data                   = ct_data
        ct_field_usage            = ct_field_usage
        ct_action_usage           = ct_action_usage
        ct_selected_lines         = ct_selected_lines
        cv_lead_index             = cv_lead_index
        cv_first_visible_row      = cv_first_visible_row
        cs_additional_info        = cs_additional_info
        ct_dnd_attributes         = ct_dnd_attributes.

DATA :
      lv_cr_number TYPE usmd_crequest,
      lv_crtype    TYPE usmd_crequest_type,
      lv_process   TYPE usmd_process.

DATA(lo_context) = cl_usmd_app_context=>get_context( ).

IF lo_context IS BOUND.
   CALL METHOD lo_context->get_attributes
        IMPORTING
          ev_crequest_id   = lv_cr_number
          ev_crequest_type = lv_crtype
          ev_process       = lv_process.
ENDIF.

IF lv_crtype EQ 'ZMDGS01'.
  READ TABLE ct_action_usage ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<lfs_copy>) WITH KEY id = 'BOL_COPY'.
   <lfs_copy>-visible = '01'.
ENDIF.

 

SAP S/4HANA SAP Master Data Governance ABAP Development 

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.
SAP Community Profile | SAP Profile | LinkedIn

entry.title: Can SAP‚Äôs Real-Time Analytics Redefine Decision-Making for the C-Suite?
entry.content:
The Changing Role of Leaders

Today‚Äôs CEOs and CTOs face more data than ever before. Numbers flow in from finance, supply chain, and customers. The challenge is not access. The challenge is speed. Leaders cannot wait days for reports. They need answers now.

Why Real-Time Matters

Traditional reporting works on past data. By the time insights reach the boardroom, the market may have moved. Real-time analytics flips this model. It brings live data from operations straight to decision-makers. A CEO can see global sales by region as they happen. A CTO can monitor system health before an outage hits.

How SAP Enables This

  • SAP HANA: stores and processes data in-memory for instant results.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): gives live dashboards and predictive models.
  • Embedded Analytics: in S/4HANA allows leaders to view insights while working inside core processes.

These tools cut delays and remove the guesswork.

Practical Example

Imagine a manufacturer facing a sudden raw material shortage. Without real-time analytics, the CEO learns of it after a weekly report. With SAP, alerts appear the moment supply drops. Leaders can adjust sourcing, update prices, and inform partners‚Äîall within hours, not days.

Best Practices for the C-Suite

  • Ask sharper questions: Real-time data works best when leaders know what to track.
  • Balance speed with accuracy: Not all data needs live updates. Focus on what drives action.
  • Build trust in data: If executives doubt the system, they will fall back on instinct.

Challenges to Watch

Real-time analytics is powerful, but not simple. Common issues include:

  • Integrating data from multiple systems.
  • Ensuring security and access control.
  • Training leaders to read dashboards, not just slides.

The Bigger Picture

Real-time analytics does not replace leadership. It sharpens it. CEOs still need vision. CTOs still need strategy. SAP‚Äôs role is to provide clear, trusted signals so leaders can act without delay.

Engage Further

The question for the C-suite is simple: Are you ready to let real-time data guide your next move? If you want to explore practical steps, connect with experts, or join discussions in the SAP Community.
